awd_titl_txt: Mathematical Theory of Resonances and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The PI investigates various problems arising in quantum and classical scattering: condensed matter physics and the study of surface states; Hawking radiation in general relativity; chaotic dynamics in statistical systems. Like a bell sounding its last notes, these problems all share a common feature: they exhibit oscillations with exponentially decaying amplitudes around an equilibrium state. A famous theoretical example concerns gravitational waves, recently detected by the LIGO detector. In technological settings, the ratio between the oscillation and decay rates to equilibrium is called the quality factor. Minimizing this ratio improves the stability and rigidity properties of the materials involved. Such technological applications include engineering graphene-like insulators; conception of waveguides and optic fibers; and design of high-quality microelectrical systems. 

The mathematical study of such phenomena relies on a unified framework called resonance theory. It investigates natural  generalizations of time-harmonic states in situations where the energy may escape or decay. Generalized energies of such states form a discrete set of complex numbers called quantum resonances (in quantum scattering), quasinormal modes (in general relativity) or Pollicott--Ruelle resonances (in dynamical systems). Their imaginary parts describe the typical frequency of the associated resonant states while the real parts describe their decay or growth outside bounded regions. Mathematically, they are the poles of the meromorphic continuation of the Hamiltonian resolvent. Much of the theoretical work consists in studying their stability and asymptotic distributions; and how they affect time evolution. This project specifically deals with the emergence of resonances under symmetry-breaking perturbations in periodic structures; the exponential convergence of Hawking radiation in black-hole spacetimes; and the relation between topology and Pollicott--Ruelle resonances in dynamical systems. Natural tools include complex analysis and Fredholm operator theory; the classical-to-quantum correspondence principle within the microlocal framework; and partial differential equations techniques such as multiscale analysis.

por.por_cntn:
Broadly speaking, this project focused on estimating characteristic lifetime of physical systems. Typically, it looked at how long and how far one can transport energy before dissipation and dispersion becomes overly significant. A day-to-day application is electricity: how does the quality and length of wires affect the intensity of a given current?

At the microscopic level, this is a condensed matter physics question: electricity is the macroscopic manifestation of electrons moving through materials (typically, metals). The most significant part of this project focused on electronic transport along edges of topological materials. These are novel structures which are insulating in their bulk but conducting along their boundary; the conducting states of such systems are usually referred to as edge states. 

While it has been known that the mere existence of edge states is immune from defects, there has been relatively few estimations of their actual profile, lifetime and speed. Such calculations are important because they inform us on the practicability of using edge states to transport energy or information: how fast is the transfer? How big is the (unavoidable) loss?

In a series of papers, the PI (a) derived effective equations for the generic dynamics of edge states in topological materials, starting with graphene; (b) constructed edge states in the semiclassical (quantum) regime; (c) evaluated their speed and variance in terms of symplectic (phase space) invariants of the system; (d) studied the extreme dispersion associated to counter-propagating edge states. Mathematically speaking, the outcome is an extensive theory of coherent states for semiclassical systems with crossings stable under the Hamiltonian (classical) dynamics.

In terms of applications, this project has demonstrated that while magnetic fields do not destroy edge states, they systematically slow them down. On the other hand, it has demonstrated that curvature does not affect their speed. These are two important observations that can serve to engineer efficient electronic devices for future technology.
